items.title: CommonJS, we love you, we love you not..
items.content:
#â€‹646 â€” July 6, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

What's Next for JavaScript: New Features to Look Forward to â€” A reassuring and high level look at just what goes into making JavaScript better over time, along with some of the new things about to appear or still making their way through the arduous TC39Â process.

Mary Branscombe (The New Stack)

Mary has followed up this piece with Beyond Browsers: The Longterm Future of JavaScript Standards which goes into more depth on JavaScript's ongoing developments in the world of servers and edge functions.

ğŸ¥ Â Remotion v4.0: Create Videos Using React â€” A powerful framework for creating videos from code using React and JavaScript. v4 is such a big update they â–¶ï¸ recorded a keynote to show itÂ off.

Jonny Burger

A Brief Primer to Engineering Efficiency â€” Software teams are dealing with many changes and budget cuts, yet still have the same delivery expectations. So, how do you keep up? ğŸ¤” The answer: invest in efficiency. Get ahead of the game with this brief on engineeringÂ efficiency.

Sleuth sponsor

'CommonJS is Hurting JavaScript' â€” An interesting take on Nodeâ€™s default module system, its history, its shortcomings, and the trickiness of managing both CommonJS and ES modules at once. It's perhaps no surprise the folks at Deno would like to see CommonJS disappear, but...

Andy Jiang (Deno)

.. the Bun team, on the other hand, say au contraire and tell us CommonJS is not going away! They explain CommonJS's plus points and why Bun is adding support forÂ it.

RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.2 Beta â€“Â Just a month after the final release of 5.1, too. using is the headline feature and the release post goes into fantasticÂ detail.

  • Node.js v20.4.0 (Current) â€“ Node gains an interesting new 'mock timers' feature for writing more reliable and deterministic tests for time-dependentÂ functionality.

  • Vite 4.4 â€“ The frontend toolkit updates to esbuild 0.18, adds experimental Lightning CSS support, and there are new starter templates for Solid and QwikÂ users.

  • Billboard.js 3.9 â€“ A popular D3-based chart library. (Demos.)

  • Deno 1.35 â€“ The alternative JS runtime makes Deno.serve() (its Web server API) stable, and improves npm and NodeÂ compatibility.

  • Bun 0.6.13

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • Jack Herrington sat down with Redux and Redux Toolkit's maintainer, Mark Erikson, to â–¶ï¸ discuss what's next for Redux and Redux Toolkit?

  • ğŸµ Spotify has introduced a TypeScript SDK for its Web API.

  • A little update from the Svelte team on the complete overhaul of their official site, hot on the heels of Svelte 4.0's release. It's a great time to be a SvelteÂ developer.

  • The folks at Imgâ€¤ly released the code for a system that can remove the backgrounds of images directly in the browser â€“ more info.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

In Defence of DOMContentLoaded â€” A solid explainer on measuring browser events and the use cases for DOMContentLoaded (and related events) in particular. "The DOMContentLoaded event fires once all of your deferred JavaScript has finishedÂ running."

Harry Roberts

Breaking Up with SVG-in-JS in 2023 â€” â€œSVGs in JS have a cost and SVGs do not belong into your JS bundle.â€ A look into why you shouldnâ€™t have SVGs in your JS bundle and better techniques for using them fromÂ JSX.

Jacob GroÃŸ

Move from Datadog to Axiom with Our New Migration App â€” Logging reimagined means Axiomâ€™s plans start at $25/mo for 1tb of data. Stop sampling, getÂ Axiom.

Axiom sponsor

An Introduction to the View Transitions API â€” The experimental View Transitions API offers an easier way to animate between DOM states and even between page loads. Hereâ€™s a look at how to use this progressiveÂ enhancement.

Craig Buckler

JavaScript Gom Jabbar â€” In the Dune universe, a â€œgom jabbarâ€ is a poisonous needle used in an eponymous test where people are subjected to intense pain. Somehow this is turned into a metaphor for painful JavaScript experiences.. ğŸ˜

Alex Kotliarskyi

â–¶Â Â The JavaScript Hype Cycle and React Burnout â€” Aaronâ€™s idea? Pick something that works for you, avoid the hype cycle, and, perhaps, donâ€™t use things that arenâ€™t at least a yearÂ old.

Aaron Francis

ğŸ“… That 'year old' thing is an interesting idea. We should introduce a section where we look back at things from a year ago and if they're still going.. ğŸ˜…

How to Consume a Paginated API using Async Generators
James Sinclair

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

MathLive: A Web Component for Math Input â€” A web component that provides an interface for editing formulas. It uses LaTeX-style typesetting to keep things looking good. GitHubÂ repo.

Arno Gourdol

Starlight: A Documentation Site Builder from Astro â€” React has Docusaurus, now Astro has Starlight. Being Astro, itâ€™s framework agnostic and you can extend it with React, Vue, Svelte, Solid, etc. You get site navigation, search, internationalization, code highlighting, dark mode, and more out of the box. GitHubÂ repo.

Starlight

Monitor, Test and Debug your APIs with APIToolkit

APIToolkit sponsor

mdsvex: A Markdown Preprocessor for Svelte â€” The homepage is a minimal, but cute, demonstration, but the docs are where the meatÂ is.

pngwn

rrule.js: Work with Recurrence Rules for Calendar Dates â€” iCalendar is a data format for representing calendars and schedules, and RRULE is its way to define recurring events. rrule.js allows you to work with such rules, and has an amazing â€˜playgroundâ€™ style homepage to show itÂ off.

Jakub Roztocil

copy-text-to-clipboard: Copy Text to Clipboard in Modern Browsers â€” Pretty simple but will save you a little messing around with the browserÂ API.

Sindre Sorhus

  • TinyBase 4.0
    â†³ Reactive data store for localâ€‘first apps.

  • Cross Fetch 4.0
    â†³ Universal WHATWG Fetch API for Node, browsers and React Native.

  • Sortable 2.2
    â†³ Makes any table with class="sortable"Â sortable.

  • Escodegen 2.1
    â†³ AST to ECMAScript code generator.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

ğŸÂ And one for luck..

Joplin: An Open Source Note Taking and To-Do App â€” Essentially an open source Evernote, complete with numerous client apps (desktop and mobile) and a server side supporting synchronization across cloud services. GitHubÂ repo.

Laurent Cozic

items.title: This is a doozy of an issue
items.content:
#â€‹645 â€” June 29, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

A Massive Bug at the Heart of the npm Ecosystem â€” â€œThis is a doozy,â€ says the author, who used to work on the npm CLI team. We donâ€™t want to spoil his story too much, but in short, package manifests and actual package contents donâ€™t necessarily match up and this can be manipulated by bad actors and even trip up auditingÂ tools.

Darcy Clarke

Useful DevTools Tips and Tricks â€” Having worked on both Firefox and Edge's devtools, Patrick knows his stuff (and shares over 100 tips on his DevTools Tips site). Here, he shares his topÂ 15.

Patrick Brosset (Microsoft)

Secure Application PII with a Simple API Call â€” Secure your app effortlessly. Shield sensitive data with minimal code using the Redact API. Use one API to redact PII, PHI, financial info, and profanity. Prioritize user safety and ensure a seamless experience. Keep it simple; keep itÂ secure.

Pangea sponsor

â–¶Â Â The Cost of JavaScript in 2023 â€” Esteemed Googler and Web performance expert Addy Osmani always brings a full, holistic view of problems and solutions to his talks, and this is no exception. He talks about the various ways JS apps are delivered and rendered, the constraints of the hardware involved, and techniques you can use to keep things runningÂ smoothly.

Addy Osmani

ğŸ’¡ I know many readers dislike videos, but no word of a lie, this is a mini masterclass in numerous modern JS and webperf topics and worth saving for later.

Introducing the MDN Playground â€” The popular Web dev docs site has branched out into the world of code sandboxes. The MDN Playground provides a space to prototype frontend ideas and expand live samples in the MDN docs into an interactiveÂ experience (such as those here).

Mozilla

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • Ecma International has approved the ECMAScript 2023 spec (as well a standard for 1 terabyte holographic disks - neat).

  • /r/javascript is one of Reddit's biggest subreddits with over 2 million followers, but it went read-only in protest of recent Reddit policies. They're now discussing whether it should come back â€“ it's not looking likely.

  • TypeScript educator Matt Pocock ğŸ¦ says the conversation has moved on from "Should we adopt TypeScript?" to "How do we best use it?"

RELEASES:

  • Ember.js 5.0 â€“ A framework that pre-dates React, is used all over the place, but that barely anyone seems to talk about (and they should).

  • styled-components 6.0 â€“ Popular CSS styling approach for React components. There's a migration guide forÂ upgraders.

  • Remix 1.18.0 â€“ The full stack framework gains big perf improvements and stabilizes its HMR/HDR-ready "new dev server" (explained).

  • esbuild 0.18.10 â€“ It's had several noteworthy enhancements in the past week so we're linking to the page covering them all.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Don't Write Console Logs Yourself Ever Again â€” We all use console.log and weâ€™ll probably use it forever, but Amit says we can save time by using the Turbo Console Log extension for VS Code to at least insert the console.log statements for us..

Amit Merchant

An Introduction to Parser Combinators â€” Parsing is rarely exciting, but Varun has done a fantastic job of making an engaging tutorial for a dry, yet extremely useful, topic. This is the bare basics, but I hope we can encourage him to finish the series :-)

Varun Ramesh

Too Much Tech Debt in Your node_modules? UpgradeJS.com CanÂ HelpÂ ğŸš€ â€” Our senior staff specializes in tech debt: @JSUpgrade will take your app from outdated/vulnerable toÂ modern/secure.

UpgradeJSâ€¤com | JS Services sponsor

An Update on Next.js's App Router Approach â€” The â€˜app routerâ€™ in Next.js 13+ offers a new approach for structuring Next apps and is recommended for all new ones going forward (it became stable in Next.js 13.4 last month). This post provides a welcome update on how the project sees the feature evolving and how the team is continuing to integrate and collaborate with ReactÂ generally.

Delba de Oliveira and Lee Robinson (Vercel)

â–¶Â Â React Server Components from Scratch: The Video â€” Dan Abramov recently released an introduction to RSCs built around reimplementing them from scratch. He asked on Twitter if anyone could record the post in video form and Jesse stepped up with a little 'dramatic reading' for addedÂ effect.

Jesse Pence

Why Doesn't TypeScript Properly Type Object.keys? â€” This provoked an extensive discussion on HackerÂ News.

Alex Harri

Making Tiled Maps with Unity and JavaScript â€” If you want to create your own Google Maps-esque, Web-rendered tiled maps, Leaflet is a great option, but how do you produce custom map tiles? Using the Unity game engine is certainly one of the more creativeÂ ways..

Alan Zucconi

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Chalk.ist: Create Attractive Images of Source Code â€” Turn your source code into beautiful images using a variety of themes and customizations. (Be sure to note accessibility requirements or issues around using suchÂ images.)

Kasper Mikiewicz

Radash 11: A Functional, Modern, Typed Utility Library â€” Thereâ€™s a live playground where you can try these out, and all 70+ utilities are described with examples in the docs. Underscore/LodashÂ vibes!

Ray Epps

Simple Statistics: Statistical Methods in Readable JS â€” A lot of the functions are quite simple, but the API is easily understood and covers areas like averages, deviations, correlation, andÂ randomness.

Tom MacWright

Shiki: A Syntax Highlighter That Uses VS Code Themes â€” Supports over 100 languages and you can specify a VS Code theme in the settings to get the look you want. Works in both Node.js and even on static sites (via a CDN build) and you can see some examplesÂ here.

Shiki

Typist: Tiptap-Based Rich Text Editor Component â€” An unashamedly opinionated yet simple text editor control. You can try the examples in the sidebar. It's suited for basic rich text situations like writing comments or messages and also has a single-lineÂ mode.

Doist

  • typescript-eslint â€“ Enables ESLint & Prettier to supportÂ TypeScript.

  • Tween.js 21.0
    â†³ JS/TS animation engine. (Examples.)

  • psd 0.4
    â†³ No dependency PSD/Photoshop parser. (Demo.)

  • DOCX 8.1
    â†³ Generate and modify Word/.docx files.

  • NodeBB 3.2 â€“ Node.js forum software.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

ğŸ˜®Â Coding in 140 characters

Wow ğŸ‘ â€“ what some people can achieve in a mere 140 characters of JS isÂ amazing. There are a lot of fantastic experiments over at Dwitter.

items.title: Svelte 4 released
items.content:
#â€‹644 â€” June 22, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

UnsuckJS: Comparing Lightweight JavaScript Options â€” "No build tools, no compilers, and noÂ hassle." Itâ€™s a table of frontend JavaScript libraries on a simple page â€“ thatâ€™s it! But itâ€™s a handy table, letting you see the relative popularity, size, and latest versions of libraries as diverse as Preact, bau, htmx, Hyperapp, andÂ Mithril.

Adam Hill

Svelte 4 Released â€” Four years on from Svelte 3.0 comes the latest major release of the popular compile-time framework that isnâ€™t afraid to do things its own way. If youâ€™re new to it, hit the interactive tutorial to get a feel for things, or if youâ€™re already a user, enjoy the v3 to v4 migration guide, overhauled site, and extra performance onÂ offer.

Rich Harris and the Svelte Team

ğŸ¤” Claudio Holanda's 'Thoughts on Svelte(Kit), one year and 3 billion requests later' provides some interesting balance to ourÂ cheerleading.

The Complete UI Component Library For Enterprise Web Apps â€” A professional UI component library with power widgets like data grid, calendar, scheduler & Gantt charts. Includes API docs, guides and an unreasonable amount of demos to play with. Seamlessly integrates with React, Angular, Vue & SalesforceÂ apps.

Bryntum sponsor

A Look at TypeScript 5.2's New Keyword: using â€” using brings something akin to Pythonâ€™s with context management into TypeScript by providing a way to automatically run a Symbol.dispose function when an object leaves scope. You could use this to shut down database connections, close file handles,Â etc.

Matt Pocock

If you're not a TS fan, the idea behind using is also an ECMAScript proposal (currently at stage 3) called Explicit Resource Management and there's more detail to enjoy in their examples.

The 'Getting Started with AI' Stack â€” Andreessen Horowitz (a.k.a. a16z) is a well known VC firm, but they also have an engineering team of their own that has come up with a â€œgetting started with AIâ€ template for JavaScript devs who want to play with modern ML technologies without too much thinking aboutÂ tooling.

Li, Li, and Casado (Andreessen Horowitz)

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • The Register reports malicious actors are exploiting expired S3 buckets to inject harmful code into legitimate npm packages without needing to modify existingÂ code.

  • Fresh, a Deno-first full-stack Web framework, has a new release in the shape of Fresh 1.2. There have been some concerns over its maintenance, but now there's a new full-time maintainer, Marvin Hagemeister, and a lot of promise on the horizon. Welcome Marvin!

RELEASES:

  • Node.js 20.3.1, 18.16.1 and 16.20.1 â€“ Security releases.

  • React Native 0.72

  • Nest 10.0 â€“ Popular Node.js framework for building enterprise-gradeÂ apps.

  • ESLint 8.43

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Synchronizing Videos or 3D Model Rotations to Scroll DrivenÂ Animations â€” With just a little JavaScript, you can control 3D models and/or videos using scroll-driven animations. Itâ€™s a common effect seen on modern fashionÂ sites.

Bramus van Damme

â–¶Â Â Recreating a JS Runtime to Understand Node's Magic â€” Popular speaker, educator, Microsoft MVP and Node.js core team member Erick gives a very enthusiastic talk on the latest â€˜hello worldâ€™ in the JavaScript world: building a runtime ğŸ˜ Somehow, Erick manages to run through the key concepts involved in just 20Â minutes.

Erick Wendel

E-Commerce Simplified â€” A practical guide to building your Store with Storyblok, Commercetools, andÂ React.js.

Storyblok sponsor

Positioning Anchored Popovers â€” Popovers are commonly positioned relative to their invoker â€” but when using the new popover attribute, anchoring can be tricky as these popovers are placed in the top layer, away from the context of their invoker. Hidde looks at options to resolveÂ this.

Hidde de Vries

â–¶Â Â React Server Components in Under Seven Minutes â€” Looking to quickly get a basic handle on RSCs? This fast-paced video tries to bootstrap you on theÂ subject.

CodeLit

A Visual Guide to Understanding Node's Event Loop
Vishwas Gopinath

Where to Host Your Remix App in 2023
Jacob Paris

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Selecto.js: Make Elements Selectable Within a Drag Area â€” Letâ€™s say you have a number of elements that represent choices, data, whatever, and you want users to be able to select a subset of them by clicking/pointing and dragging. Thatâ€™s what this does. Live examplesÂ here.

Daybrush (Younkue Choi)

Tuple â€“ The Fastest Way to Onboard New Devs â€” Waste hours verbally steering on Zoom? New hires learn your codebase faster with Tuple. Trusted by over 40,000Â devs.

Tuple sponsor

AutoAnimate: Add Motion to Your Apps with a Single Line of Code â€” You can view some nice examples on the page and this can be used with React, Vue, Svelte, or just plainÂ JavaScript.

FormKit

Toad Scheduler: In-Memory Node and Browser Job Scheduler â€” Provides more structure than setTimeout or setInterval and supports cron-styleÂ scheduling.

Igor Savin

Kysely: A Fluent, Type-Safe SQL Query Builder â€” Inspired by Knex and targeting Node, it also works in Deno and the browser and boasts a good autocompletion experience thanks to its fluent API. GitHubÂ repo.

Sami KoskimÃ¤ki

AI.JSX: A JSX-Powered AI App Framework â€” Itâ€™s not React, but gives a React-like feel to letting you specify how large language models, such as ChatGPT, should integrate with your app. Luckily thereâ€™s a set ofÂ tutorials.

Fixie.ai

Generate SBOMs Effortlessly with Snyk

Snyk sponsor

ğŸ’¡ An SBOM is a "software bill of materials" â€“ essentially an inventory of dependencies and components that make up an application, as Liran Tal explains.

ğŸ¼ Â Panda CSS: Modern, Build-Time, Type-Safe CSS-in-JS â€” A new DX-focused CSS-in-JS approach boasting build-time generated styles and type safety out of the box. It works with Remix, Vite, Next.js, Astro, and serverÂ components.

Segun Adebayo

React Wrap Balancer 1.0: A Component for Better Displayed TitleÂ Text â€” A component that improves the rendering of titles by avoiding overhanging words. v1.0 is a key release that lets the component use the native CSS text-wrap property whenÂ supported.

Shu Ding

  • Perspective 2.3 â€“ Data visualization and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled to WebAssembly where it can be used from JavaScript.

  • Tesseract.js 4.1.1 â€“ Pure JS OCR for 100+ languages. Fixes a key bug for processing images taken with iOS devices.

  • Shoelace 2.5
    â†³ Well designed, framework agnostic UI component suite.

  • TestCafe 3.0
    â†³ Node.js tool to automated end-to-end testing.

  • AlaSQL 4.1
    â†³ JS SQL database for browser and Node.

  • Octokit.js 2.1
    â†³ GitHub SDK for browsers, Node, and Deno.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

#â€‹644 â€” June 22, 2023


Read on the Web



JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
UnsuckJS: Comparing Lightweight JavaScript Options â€” "No build tools, no compilers, and noÂ hassle." Itâ€™s a table of frontend JavaScript libraries on a simple page â€“ thatâ€™s it! But itâ€™s a handy table, letting you see the relative popularity, size, and latest versions of libraries as diverse as Preact, bau, htmx, Hyperapp, andÂ Mithril.
Adam Hill 


  
  
Svelte 4 Released â€” Four years on from Svelte 3.0 comes the latest major release of the popular compile-time framework that isnâ€™t afraid to do things its own way. If youâ€™re new to it, hit the interactive tutorial to get a feel for things, or if youâ€™re already a user, enjoy the v3 to v4 migration guide, overhauled site, and extra performance onÂ offer.
Rich Harris and the Svelte Team 


ğŸ¤” Claudio Holanda's 'Thoughts on Svelte(Kit), one year and 3 billion requests later' provides some interesting balance to ourÂ cheerleading.





  
  
The Complete UI Component Library For Enterprise Web Apps â€” A professional UI component library with power widgets like data grid, calendar, scheduler & Gantt charts. Includes API docs, guides and an unreasonable amount of demos to play with. Seamlessly integrates with React, Angular, Vue & SalesforceÂ apps.
Bryntum sponsor


  
  
A Look at TypeScript 5.2's New Keyword: using â€” using brings something akin to Pythonâ€™s with context management into TypeScript by providing a way to automatically run a Symbol.dispose function when an object leaves scope. You could use this to shut down database connections, close file handles,Â etc.
Matt Pocock 


If you're not a TS fan, the idea behind using is also an ECMAScript proposal (currently at stage 3) called Explicit Resource Management and there's more detail to enjoy in their examples.

items.title: 11 years of JavaScript on top
items.content:
#â€‹643 â€” June 15, 2023

Read on the Web

âœï¸ Be sure to make it to the end of today's issue because we have an interview with the creator of Angular and Qwik, MiÅ¡ko Hevery, about exactly what Qwik brings to the modern JavaScript development table. Spoiler: performance and resumability.
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

Val Town: If GitHub Gists Could Run, and AWS Lambda Were Fun â€” Iâ€™ve been keeping an eye on this for a few months and itâ€™s a fascinating idea rapidly turning into a useful service that's going places. You write bite size chunks of JavaScript and Val Town runs them in a sandbox, lets them call each other, lets you schedule them, or serves them up over HTTP. Itâ€™s smart and worth aÂ look.

Steve Krouse

The Stack Overflow Developer Survey 2023 Results â€” Over 90,000 developers took Stack Overflowâ€™s annual survey and itâ€™s all "coming up Milhouse" â–¶ï¸ for JavaScript (and TypeScript too, natch) with JS topping the popularity charts 11 years in a row. Its showing is somewhat poorer in the top paying technologies list, but we canâ€™t haveÂ itÂ all.

Stack Overflow

Enterprise UI Development: Testing & Code Quality â€” Managing or migrating large apps and codebases? This video course covers what you need to know to scale efficiently whilst maintaining code quality. Covers unit testing, CI pipelines, mocking, code coverage, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Melange 1.0: Compile OCaml / ReasonML to JavaScript â€” Having started life as a fork of BuckleScript, Melange now pitches itself as a mature tool for compiling OCaml (a popular functional programming language) to efficient and readableÂ JavaScript.

Antonio Nuno Monteiro, Hongbo Zhang et al.

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • Chrome for Testing is a new, official Chrome 'flavor' specifically targeting web testing and automation use cases. You can already use it with Puppeteer.

  • Angular's ng-conf event is currently taking place, and the latest news is the release of Angular 16.1 (now with TypeScript 5.1 support), an RFC for a new control flow syntax, and an RFC for built-in declarative lazy loading.

  • Allegedly, you can't currently publish npm packages containing the words 'keygen' or 'cheat' in their names. Hacker News has been discussing it and a response from npm is currently being awaited.

  • Terence Eden has come up with a way to password protect a static HTML page with no JavaScript but it's such an odd approach that you might not want to use it in production ğŸ˜†

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v20.3.0 (Current)

  • VS Code May 2023 Edition â€“ Adds a JS refactoring to move a class, function, or constant into an existing file and update all references.

  • Bun 0.6.9 â€“Â Mostly fixes and memory efficiencies for the alternative JS runtime. Nice.

  • TS-Pattern 5.0
    â†³ Exhaustive pattern matching library for TypeScript.

  • NestJS 10.0 â€“ Progressive Node.js app framework. (What's new.)

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

An Introduction to Debugging Tools and Approaches for Node â€” An informative primer on debugging, from simple things like using IDE extensions to highlight potential problems or, yes, console logging, through to using the V8 inspector and debugging viaÂ Chrome.

Craig Buckler

Before Your Next Frontend PullÂ Request, Use This Checklist â€” Avoid common mistakes in pull requests with this checklist, covering areas from minimizing bundle size and ensuring accessibility to using semantic markup and keeping codeÂ clean.

Nina Torgunakova

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby.js sponsor

â–¶Â Â Nuxt Explained in 100 Seconds â€” One of Fireshipâ€™s typical fast-paced high level roundups. This time they cover Nuxt, the Vue-oriented appÂ framework.

Fireship

How To Build Server-Side Rendered (SSR) Svelte Apps with SvelteKit â€” SvelteKit is a framework for building apps using Svelte. This post walks through creating a simple job board with it and deploying onÂ Netlify.

Sriram Thiagarajan

â–¶Â Â Learn Angular Routing in 35 Minutes
Ervis Trupja

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Motion Canvas: A TypeScript Library and Real-Time Preview Editor to Program Animations â€” Uses generator functions to procedurally define your animations, and you can try out the web-based editor that allows you to work with the animationsÂ visually.

Motion Canvas

Code Together Before You Work Together. Interview Devs in a Real IDE â€” Skip algorithm interviews & use CoderPad to run coding interviews that are trusted by both candidates andÂ interviewers.

CoderPad sponsor

Threlte: A Three.js Scene Renderer and Component Library for Svelte â€” react-three-fiber is great, but if you prefer Svelte, this is the alternative for you. It appears to be under very active development too with a whole new version on the way soon. GitHubÂ repo.

Grischa Erbe

Million.js: A Performance-Focused VDOM Replacement for React â€” Starting life two years ago as a small, library-agnostic virtual DOM implementation, Million has recently presented itself as a performance enhancement for React: â€œImagine React components running at the speed of rawÂ JavaScript.â€

Aiden Bai

ğŸ“° We featured this in this week's React Status newsletter â€“ if you're a React developer, we focus more heavily on React news there.

jest-extended 4.0: Additional Matchers for Jest Users â€” If youâ€™re using Jest for testing, this project introduces a variety of more specific matchers for various situations, particularly around type, value and formatÂ checking.

Jest Community

Rewind-UI: Customizable React + Tailwind CSS Component Library â€” A React component library fitting into the Tailwind CSS way of thinking. You can play with a live demo of some basic customizations on the homepage. Itâ€™s in beta but there are about thirty components to sink your teethÂ into.

Nick Dunas

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity

Userfront sponsor

â±ğŸŒ Â tz-lookup 8.0: Fast Time Zone Estimations from Latitude andÂ Longitude â€” â€œThis package trades speed and size for accuracy.â€ If you need to quickly infer timezone from location in Node or the browser, it's worth a try.

Matthew McEachen

SVG.js v3.2: SVG Manipulation and Animation Library â€” A lightweight approach without dependencies. Thereâ€™s a demo on JSFiddle you can play with. GitHubÂ repo.

Various Authors

  • Vue-ECharts 6.6
    â†³ Apache ECharts component for Vue.js. (Demo.)

  • Neutralino.js 4.12.0 â€“ JS desktop app framework.

  • Mineflayer 4.9 â€“ Create Minecraft bots in JavaScript.

  • Tremor 3.1 â€“ React dashboard building library.

  • â™– React Chessboard 3.0 â€“ Yes, a chess component!

  • React Calendar 4.3

Dehydrating the Web with...
MiÅ¡ko Hevery

Perhaps best known as the creator of Angular, MiÅ¡ko is on a fresh mission with Qwik. Recently reaching v1.0 and focusing on the 'instant' delivery of full-stack apps to end users, Qwik takes an interesting approach around 'streaming' JavaScript to the client only when needed.

MiÅ¡ko recently shared the full story of Qwik â–¶ï¸ on the Stack Overflow podcast, and we wanted to ask him a few questions here too:

What was the key inspiration behind Qwik?

I don't think there was a "key" inspiration but an accumulation of things that made me realize the current approach doesn't scale.

We did a lot of work making the Ivy compiler in Angular faster and more capable. While we had a lot of success, the speed wins were not obvious. While Ivy was optimized, the rest of the app was not, and at app startup the code ran without optimization because the VM hadn't warmedÂ up.

Google has an internal framework called WIZ that powers Google Search, Flights, and Photos. WIZ is great at not executing a lot of code on app startup, and it results in a better user experience.

The realization that code runs more slowly on app startup and that it's proportional to the amount of JS to execute, is what led me to building a framework that would not need to execute code eagerly on startup. Qwik is the culmination of that goal.

What is Qwik's biggest differentiator to other frameworks?

Qwik is resumable. Qwik can transfer its internal state from the server to the client, which means that the app can become interactive on the client without having to execute any app-related code eagerly.

Resumablity is at the heart of Qwik. Qwik apps can resume because Qwik knows how to serialize the state of the app and the framework. Other frameworks know how to serialize the app state but not necessarily the framework state.

(Editor's note: Think Qwik goes into more detail on this.)

Some developers have strong opinions about the use of symbols like $ in names. Did you have any qualms and did you consider any alternatives?

Some people have visceral reactions to $ as it reminds them of jQuery orÂ PHP.

Qwik needs a way to mark closures for extraction. JavaScript doesn't have an easy syntax for doing this so we needed to come up with our own. $ communicates to the optimizer that it needs to perform code extraction at that location, and also communicates to the developer that special rules apply there too.

We chose $ as it's one of the few non-alpha characters valid in function names and that does not change the pronunciation of the API.

Misko is CTO at Builder.io and creator of Qwik.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Got a job listing to share? Here's how.

Dehydrating the Web with...
MiÅ¡ko Hevery
 
     
    
Perhaps best known as the creator of Angular, MiÅ¡ko is on a fresh mission with Qwik. Recently reaching v1.0 and focusing on the 'instant' delivery of full-stack apps to end users, Qwik takes an interesting approach around 'streaming' JavaScript to the client only when needed.
MiÅ¡ko recently shared the full story of Qwik â–¶ï¸ on the Stack Overflow podcast, and we wanted to ask him a few questions here too:
What was the key inspiration behind Qwik?
I don't think there was a "key" inspiration but an accumulation of things that made me realize the current approach doesn't scale.
We did a lot of work making the Ivy compiler in Angular faster and more capable. While we had a lot of success, the speed wins were not obvious. While Ivy was optimized, the rest of the app was not, and at app startup the code ran without optimization because the VM hadn't warmedÂ up.
Google has an internal framework called WIZ that powers Google Search, Flights, and Photos. WIZ is great at not executing a lot of code on app startup, and it results in a better user experience.
The realization that code runs more slowly on app startup and that it's proportional to the amount of JS to execute, is what led me to building a framework that would not need to execute code eagerly on startup. Qwik is the culmination of that goal.
What is Qwik's biggest differentiator to other frameworks?
Qwik is resumable. Qwik can transfer its internal state from the server to the client, which means that the app can become interactive on the client without having to execute any app-related code eagerly.
Resumablity is at the heart of Qwik. Qwik apps can resume because Qwik knows how to serialize the state of the app and the framework. Other frameworks know how to serialize the app state but not necessarily the framework state.
(Editor's note: Think Qwik goes into more detail on this.)
Some developers have strong opinions about the use of symbols like $ in names. Did you have any qualms and did you consider any alternatives?
Some people have visceral reactions to $ as it reminds them of jQuery orÂ PHP.
Qwik needs a way to mark closures for extraction. JavaScript doesn't have an easy syntax for doing this so we needed to come up with our own. $ communicates to the optimizer that it needs to perform code extraction at that location, and also communicates to the developer that special rules apply there too.
We chose $ as it's one of the few non-alpha characters valid in function names and that does not change the pronunciation of the API.


Misko is CTO at Builder.io and creator of Qwik.
